posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: Considering switching from 6 AWG wires to 4 AWG wires for next season, we almost made the change this season but decided against it because the effort required outweighed the benefits gained. I’m curious about why your teams prefer 4 AWG wires and whether the effort involved, such as reworking your charging setup, was worth it for you.

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

@sdtrent did a presentation at the championship about his teams’ experience. It’s worth a read/watch. He shared it in another topic under Chief Delphi.

posts.name: Battery Nerd - FRC #4561
posts.cooked: @MetabolicCloth. Thanks for the mention about the seminar! @elctrilica The link below has notes on our journey changing to larger wire size while keeping the SB50 connectors, and all of our SB50 connected chargers, testers, etc. There are a couple of cautions, attention to detail is important when trimming the 2ga cable down to fit the system terminals, and PDH (see cautionary tale). Slides from my Houston robot power presentation. And a link to the presentation video. Please refer to the attached document for more details. Thank you! Shane

link_counts.title: 2ga Battery Cables and TerrorByte Terminals - Google Docs
Robot Power Delivery: Maximizing Performance - Google Slides

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
It’s somewhat difficult to gauge this year due to the reduced power demands on our 2025 robots compared to our 2024 models.

In general, switching to 4AWG cables offers improved robustness and reduces system resistance. Additionally, using Anderson SB50 connectors alongside 4AWG cables is cost-effective, as it allows us to modify fewer components (only the batteries) rather than replacing all SB50 connectors (batteries, chargers, and robots). However, further testing in a power-intensive game would provide clearer insights into its impact on performance.

link_counts.title: Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics

posts.name: David Kravets
posts.cooked: Does your power wire feel hot to the touch after a match? If yes, it's worth upgrading to thicker cabling. However, it's not as simple as just turning on the heat; even thinner wires can become warm under load. For instance, my 4AWG cables can get quite toasty after half an hour of continuous play, which is why some teams opt for thicker gauges like 2AWG or even higher. Conversely, if your setup doesn't generate much heat after a match, sticking with thinner gauges like 6AWG could save you money while maintaining performance.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
4 AWG is the biggest size that doesn't require a lot of extra work. It feels like the right balance between price, performance, and annoyance. If you strip a #4 wire and immediately stuff it into the SB50 #6 lugs, it should fit without twisting. Start at the ban angle and swing it into alignment! Typically, only a few stray strands need clipping.  
I built and did the lug expansion, but found it wasn't necessary. My measurements from a distance clearly showed the difference, aligning with predictions. Note that the breakers and the copper in the power panel become significant at this stage!

posts.name: Tanmay Darji
posts.cooked: If you switch over to 4AWG, I highly recommend the Windynation welding wire. It fits perfectly into the SB-50 crimps with minimal effort and is extremely flexible—a trait our drive team really values. Working with it feels amazing!

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
It depends on where your team is on the robot performance curve, and how much budget you have to spend on this. ~90% of teams don't need to worry about it. Get your drive gearing correct—maybe go a little conservative on it—in the SDS system stick to L2, get your superstructure gearing a bit conservative, and focus on good processes around your battery terminations, protecting the wire paths to your terminal lugs, etc. Allocate your budget and process improvements toward avoiding catastrophic failure instead of pursuing marginal gains. For example, switching to 4awg isn't just about saving money; it's about protecting your robot.

~9% of teams already measure robot actions precisely to the tenth of a second and invest in high-quality batteries, building custom power systems. These teams should consider adding 4awg in SB50s as a small optimization. While not mandatory, doing so can enhance performance without worrying about brownouts. We implemented this between 2019 and 2024, adjusting our approach based on less aggressive drive gearing and shorter sprint distances this year, which also helped prevent brownout issues.

Bottom line: A loose lug with 4awg is just as dangerous as one with 6awg.

Bottom line: 4awg main power is a relatively easy way to improve performance slightly but isn't essential for success.

(Among the final ~1% of teams, some use SB120s for an additional 1% boost.)

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
People often mention that 4awg wire and SB120 provide only minor performance improvements, which may not secure victories on their own. These solutions are insufficient for most competitions. Instead, teams should allocate their resources where they can have the greatest impact.

I strongly suggest prioritizing investments such as purchasing eight new batteries annually and maintaining sufficient quality chargers and practice batteries. This approach offers significant long-term benefits compared to upgrading to 4awg wire unless you've already made substantial investments in secure wiring, reliable batteries, and sturdy connections.

In summary, each upgrade should be evaluated based on its value relative to the cost.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Personally, I believe buying 8 new batteries every season along with sufficient quality chargers to maintain them and your practice batteries will be a much better investment for most teams. Having enough charge ensures reliability, especially when compared to FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) batteries, which are known for wearing out quickly due to the extreme conditions they face during matches. Teams often hear stories of batteries being replaced multiple times within a single season because of the intense competition and wear-and-tear involved.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
Weldingrod1: I built and did the lug expansion, but found it just wasn't needed.

This year, I used a Banebot wheel hub with set screws and a 1/4-inch pin to expand SB50 terminals, which worked surprisingly well and made it easy for students.

I definitely feel that 4 AWG wire gauge isn't critical for battery applications. My order from the battery presentation at Massive Mini included components listed last.

Here is the rest of it: [Link to Google Slides presentation]

I'm interested in checking out the conference talk to incorporate any additional knowledge.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
